title: Make Opcode Updates Seamless for the End User

chats.content: Moving a discussion from #51.Without repeating all of the notes from above, there might be a worthwhile enhancement to the OverlayPlugin release cycle around updating opcodes. Generally, opcode changes aren't engaging to the end user, thus create a mandatory, yet relatively low value, update prompt when the end user opens ACT or manually checks for new updates.Because of this, there should be some mechanism that drives the necessary end user engagement down. It would also be worthwhile if this could drive the maintainer cost down as well, since creating a release is not automatic. There's various possible options to take here, but to name some at a high level that could work well with the given ecosystem:Check remote GitHub for changes to opcodes.json in the backgroundHave GitHub actions cut a release and automatically push it when opcodes.json is updatedCreate an option for the end user to automatically consume updatesThe first solves both sides of the issue, but is then potentially downloading something without the end user's consent, which, given the size, content, and mechanism, is probably okay. The other two both don't individually solve both parts of the issue and would require some additional component to address the spirit of this issue.My personal take would be to opt for the last option presented above and then continue to work to remove pains from the maintainers' lifecycle since most people maintaining this project have other projects (in addition to their other commitments); however, that shouldn't be seen as a blocker since I believe effectively all of these options can be mixed and matched to come up with a workable solution.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

Replying to @xpdota from the other thread:Would having it automatically update when it sees that the game version is not found in the opcodes file work? I think the case that that doesn't handle is if someone gets the opcode wrong, pushes an update with it, but since that would be uncommon, you could just manually push a release with the fixed code.I think this would work well enough as well; it provides an optimization that would make checking GitHub less necessary (probably not necessary from GitHub's end, but definitely being a better user of the platform). I don't exactly know how opcodes work well enough to know how they work across the various locales, but, from how they look at a surface-level, this sounds sufficient enough to approach bringing down the number of checks.There's still an issue at the end of this where does OverlayPlugin simply use the values it found from GitHub or does it attempt to also write to disk (potentially overwriting opcodes.json or writing it somewhere as a temporary means until the next update)?I think there's pros and cons to each approach, but I don't think that making network calls is a very strong con, but it would mean that the next OverlayPlugin release does have to come "eventually" so that the plugin sees that it has the available opcode. Inversely, if OverlayPlugin downloads the new opcodes.json, theoretically the plugin could continue to work for long periods of time without an official release. The downside there obviously being that any failed update will be much harder to troubleshoot. All reactions

I think in my imagining of this, it would cache them somewhere (on disk, in OverlayPlugin config) so that it could permanently continue to work for long periods of time without a release.I think if there is a continuous failed update for some reason, the log should already have No opcodes for game version {version} in it.This should make it obvious enough when debugging as "what's in the log" is a pretty common question.(I think a bunch of those should get upgraded to errors, but it should be ok as-is right now too.)The idea of only checking when it can't be found makes a lot of sense to me and simplifies a lot of things. All reactions
I think that to me it makes the most sense to check once on ACT start, and just follow the already existing Automatically check for updates checkbox on the General tab. All reactions

title: Lines vs Events

chats.content: Before we add too many new line types, I wanted to have a brief discussion and solicit feelings about guidelines for adding new lines.Ravahn sent some guidance that they were a little concerned about adding lines that were too noisy and would create additional log processing delays for people who are already having this issue.Obviously it's multidimensionally subjective what "too many" log lines is based on existing logs, content, people's computers, but I think it's something to keep in mind.In my mind, OverlayPlugin now has two methods for providing data: lines and events.Network lines are an event itself, but they behave differently in that lines are stored on disk and almost every overlay subscribes to the log event.Only people running an overlay that subscribes to other events will get that data.I would also argue that there's probably more processing per-line than per-event just based on the fact that there are more implicit subscribers to lines than to events.Lines are also a way to get data to Triggernometry or fflogs in a way that events are not.In my mind, here's what I imagine as a criteria for lines vs events:Lines: data for triggers, data used for log analysis/imports/playbackEvents: things that are more ephemeral, data for UI (e.g. job stuff, enmity stuff)To apply this to various hypothetical data sources:Custom line registration: line, because needed for importing/analysisMap events: line, because needed for triggersFates/CEs: event?, not really something you would write a trigger for, ephemeral data, not really needed for analysis/playbackFishing !/!!/!!! headmarkers: line, not combat data but is something people would want to write triggers forA8S/P1S weapon attachment data: line, because needed for triggersStart/Stop combat: line, needed when importing to split encounters properlyTargeting changes: event, since ephemeral and not really needed for triggers?Am I overthinking this? Do other people have other heuristics they'd rather apply? Does anybody have a suggestion of what a "% of log lines" we should be trying to aim for or be concerned about with new log line types?I certainly think that probably we are at a point where we will add a bunch of lines in the short term but it will slow down after that.However, I mostly want to come to some consensus before adding too many.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

Really the heart of the question for me is to separate out "is this data worth logging to disk, and having all of our log-processing machinery chew through it" vs "is this data just something that we want OverlayPlugin to provide in some form or another".I think this is my bias, but my preference also is to have any log lines OverlayPlugin provides to always be in the log file and to not be configurable or optional.I do enough tech support already for people who have chat lines off or various other configuration weirdness to not want to have even more knobs to have to go look at to understand why something is broken or missing from a log file. All reactions

Short version for me is: I don't care, I can use either (or in some cases both, so that both log replaying and live work equally well, since the event can be cached). Since I can record the entire Websocket input, I can also capture whatever stuff doesn't have a log line.Things like targeting changes can be useful for triggers (think tank swaps). I think if you really stretch it, just about anything could be useful as a line. Rather than choosing "debate what is useful enough to be in the log" as the long-term solution, do we instead just standardize a "saved websocket session" format that includes everything? There's already issues of live vs replay reproducibility because of things like combatant positions not always accurately being reflected in the log at the time of a cast, so saving the entire socket flow is the only way to get existing functionality fully working when replaying anyway. All reactions

Sort of off on a tangent here, but re: performance.I'd really like to get some profiler data from someone with a weaker machine to see what's slowing down log line processing the most.I've never had issues with log line processing, even in world fates with 300+ people and Log all Network Packets enabled, with my i7 8700k.I can only assume this is some issue C#-side with processing the lines, or at the HDD level with writing to/reading from the file, as anything overlay-side regardless of the point of processing is happening in another thread which would never trigger the "log processing running behind" error message.If it's C#-side, it would fall into one of two camps:ACT itself/FFXIV_ACT_Plugin - Nothing we can do about itOverlayPlugin/Cactbot/Triggernometry/some other open-source project - Improve performance to help alleviate issuesRe: the original thrust of this issue. I guess the question from me is that, are there cases where we as devs will want e.g. Fate/CE lines, or other lines in the future, which won't really be needed by end-users?Fishing !/!!/!!! headmarkers: line, not combat data but is something people would want to write triggers forThis is a curious example because I believe that we could currently support "lines" like these for triggers without ever writing them to file, by invoking https://advancedcombattracker.com/apidoc/html/M_Advanced_Combat_Tracker_FormActMain_ParseRawLogLine.htm, which is maybe a whole other discussion.Should we allow the registering caller to indicate via parameter if the event type should be "write to disk" vs "emit as line only" vs "fire an event"? All reactions

Personally, I haven't seen the ACT is having trouble parsing logs message in a very long time; I don't think it was related to any hardware changes, but maybe. I also had the initial thought in the same vein as valarnin in that "can logs just be processed faster (or in parallel)?" Although that skirts the true design issue here for the sake of a bandaid (albeit maybe effective enough).I think as far as the other things listed here -- I don't think any existing logs can really be removed without causing some detriment (if that were even an available option), which leads into the same situation on the other side once additional logs have been added -- they're hard to take away once added.As for some heuristic to what's okay to put in and what isn't, I really couldn't say. Likely you want things that cause triggers to be available within logs for the sake of debugging, changing, etc. (extending down to base ACT, as far as I'm concerned). We could say that MapEvents are okay and necessary given the evolution of fight mechanics, but comparing a modern fight to one from A Realm Reborn will have very different logging amounts for things like that, making it relatively difficult to gate what is and isn't okay based off volume, leaving us with (as far as I can see) two metrics: value added and accessibility.I consider the former to be the more obvious: How nice would it be to have a trigger? And the latter to be how nice it would be to have just that log line without supplemental logic. I don't know the full state of the third party ecosystem (I think one point of this post), but if everyone is capable of using events and a log line is not useful at a fundamental level, it may be worth not logging. However, at that point, then debugging will likely be more difficult without some way for all plugins to capture and preserve and output these events.To the parallelism point in parentheses above, I think things can be logged into some sidecar log file, but I (again) don't know if that addresses the points made in quisquous' second post. Anyway, this is all to say I think it's somewhat nebulous and unless the tooling gets a lot better for the average user to create support files for debugging I think most things will default to being logged. Which then leads to, maybe implement the least amount upfront and try to peel off things one at a time. In this same vein, I would also say anything that grows sublinearly with log amounts is probably also "okay" here; for example, if there were a log line added at the start of every instance to calculate the random offset for items and head markers, since that could then be used in the logic of other callouts (or maybe eventually just fix all of the head markers in their log lines -- going back to the accessibility point above). All reactions

One counterpoint - if we were to have something like one line to give us the headmarker offset, or something like RSVs, there is value in having that be available as an event rather than a log line (pretend it's not feasible to just fix up the headmarker/ability lines with the corrected offset/RSV values), since an event supports clients that connect after the zone has started. That's one of the biggest advantages of events over log lines IMO (or at the very least, is a reason to do both in those circumstances, like for map/zone/party changes).Also, something that I don't think is talked about is the sheer variance in number of log lines simply due to a user's battle log settings (or whether they have the "hide chat log for privacy" setting enabled). A simple cast/snapshot/resolve goes from 3 lines to 6 if the relevant battle log options are enabled. I think it's probably fine to tell someone "hey, if you're seeing your parsing lag behind, turn off unused battle log stuff as a workaround". You've also got some plugins dumping their debug log as fake echo chat lines, which would have a disproportionate impact on performance because any regex/parsing looking for echo lines will have to process further into the line before throwing it out. All reactions

Re: log lines for things that only happen on zone-in such as RSV or headmarker offset info, I don't think that's feasible anyways because it'll break if someone doesn't have ACT open when zoning in, or has to restart ACT mid-zone. All triggers should be written as if ACT were started 15 seconds before the pull, because that's the case fairly often. All reactions

Someone might have ACT open, but not have the overlay/client connected yet (think remote cactbot), perhaps the overlay itself just hasn't fully connected yet, or just someone restarting the WS client for dev/debugging purposes. Same idea as zone/map/party change - these work fine if the overlay connects after the lines have been emitted because OP can cache it. At the same time, they're driven by log lines in the first place, so in most of these cases, the answer is "do both options". I'd advocate for that, since it still works if you open a plain log file.But I still think it is a good idea to have an "enhanced log" format that captures websocket data rather than just log lines. As I mentioned earlier, some triggers require accurate combatants data to function correctly (even if the log line itself has stale data), meaning you need a capture of that data for them to be properly testable. I do this anyway because sometimes there's even more data sources needed for an accurate reconstruction (e.g. I currently need Telesto for a properly sorted party list). All reactions

I have some thoughts with regards to more accurate combatant data going forward but that's not really directly relevant to this discussion.Circling back around to the "how many lines is too many" question, I think I can summarize my thoughts as:Extra lines during a time where lines aren't really heavy anyways (e.g. fate/CE lines in overworld zones) should be fine as long as they're not extremely spammyExtra lines during heavy combat (24-man content or 48-man content) should be heavily scrutinized since those are the most likely to impact performanceExtra lines during normal 8-man content should be fine as long as they aren't excessiveAs far as the question of "line vs event", I think that anything generated based off of network data should be a line. Even if it's spammy, that spam can be reduced/eliminated by C#-side processing before emitting the line. There's no point in making it an event for queue-ing purposes if there's always a chance that ACT wasn't open when the line arrived to begin with, that will just lead to inconsistent behavior.Note that map change/player change/misc other info as mentioned elsewhere are detected via memory by FFXIV_ACT_Plugin, not via network data, that's why they always get emitted when ACT is started. All reactions

There's no point in making it an event for queue-ing purposes if there's always a chance that ACT wasn't open when the line arrived to begin with, that will just lead to inconsistent behavior.It might lead to inconsistent behavior, but better to generally have it than not as long as nothing is dependent on it for anything more than bells and whistles. e.g. before ChangeMap got a cached event to go along with the log line, the only impact to me was not seeing the map background image. It's still better to have it cached than not cached, since it's only used to improve a UI view.But again, I don't think these are necessarily mutually exclusive. It's really more of a 3-way choice - line, event, or both. Generally, I think that when you factor in caching behavior, any client that connects to the WS should be able to reconstruct state, just as if it had been connected the instant ACT started up. If ACT itself missed the line, then you wouldn't have that data either way. All reactions

Circling back around to the "how many lines is too many" question, I think I can summarize my thoughts as:Extra lines during a time where lines aren't really heavy anyways (e.g. fate/CE lines in overworld zones) should be fine as long as they're not extremely spammyExtra lines during heavy combat (24-man content or 48-man content) should be heavily scrutinized since those are the most likely to impact performanceExtra lines during normal 8-man content should be fine as long as they aren't excessiveThis makes sense to me as a guideline.I am sorry to put up such a nebulous discussion here.I know there's not really great answers.I just wanted to see where thoughts were.As far as the question of "line vs event", I think that anything generated based off of network data should be a line. Even if it's spammy, that spam can be reduced/eliminated by C#-side processing before emitting the line. There's no point in making it an event for queue-ing purposes if there's always a chance that ACT wasn't open when the line arrived to begin with, that will just lead to inconsistent behavior.I think this is somewhat unclear, as the line (pun not intended) between network and memory data is murky.Memory data is there because network data has been sent, and some code has executed, changing memory.So, memory data is just indirect network data.It may be in an easier form or easier to find, but it's all "data from the server" in my opinion.In terms of OverlayPlugin WS clients missing lines due to startup, I would maybe suggest that we do something similar to what I did for cactbot's log splitter.I found that you could split lines into three categories: (1) lines that always need to be included (startup versions, etc), (2) lines that you only need the last instance of (zone changing, player name, party), (3) lines that you don't need to be cached at all.We could have an explicit "give me the cached lines" request.(Maybe rsv lines create a 4th category of "lines to send once per zone, clear when zoning")We could also just send these cached lines immediately when a client connects as the first lines they receive.That way we wouldn't need to add an event that corresponds with lines just so it can be requested. For whatever it's worth here's my opinion on the matter and my intentions when I implemented the event sources in the first place:I don't like log lines as a data transport because they often have way too much overhead. Most overlays that subscribe to log lines only use a small fraction of the lines. For all the ignored lines, we're wasting CPU time with JSON serialisation and IPC (C# -> C++ -> sandbox -> JS) and lines that are used still waste CPU time because each overlay does its own log parsing so in extreme cases the same line gets parsed 10 times (since 10 different overlays use the same log line).Event sources and events in general were supposed to solve this issue by moving the whole parsing out of JS and making subscriptions more granular. My goal was to eventually phase out log lines for overlays entirely (and offering the same data through events instead) but I doubt this is possible since there will always be overlays that use log lines even if all the data they need is available through events.The only reason I see to generate new log lines in OverlayPlugin would be to make additional data available to other plugins like Triggernometry.This is a curious example because I believe that we could currently support "lines" like these for triggers without ever writing them to file, by invoking advancedcombattracker.com/apidoc/html/M_Advanced_Combat_Tracker_FormActMain_ParseRawLogLine.htm, which is maybe a whole other discussion.This is exactly what I did in that case:OverlayPlugin/OverlayPlugin.Core/Integration/UnstableNewLogLines.csLines 113 to 121in9b2a5df public void WriteLogMessage(string msg){var time = DateTime.Now;var lineParts = new string[] { "00", time.ToString(), "c0fe", "", "OPLine: " + msg, "" };var line = string.Join("|", lineParts); ActGlobals.oFormActMain.ParseRawLogLine(false, time, line);logQueue?.Enqueue(line);} Something else I wanted to do with UnstableNewLogLines is log raw data that is used to generate events which could then be used to replay those events with a log but I never got around to that.Regarding missed log lines: This is an issue that affects both WS clients and normal overlays. The FFXIV plugin starts emitting log lines during start up which in extreme cases can lead to OverlayPlugin itself missing log lines since they're emitted before it even registers the event listener. Even if OverlayPlugin is registered in time to catch the log lines, the overlay might still be loading and thus miss the log line as well.With cached events, subscribing to an event immediately triggers the event using the cached value for the given subscriber which makes the whole thing pretty seamless (since the overlay can't tell if the event was created using cached data or not).Regarding performance:OverlayPlugin itself is pretty light on CPU load since it doesn't really do much with log lines. Most of the time is spent on JSON serialisation and in Chromium code (which has to hand off the message to the actual renderer process).Often, when someone complained about performance issues on the ACT Discord, Triggernometry's benchmark showed that their many triggers took 0.3s per log line or something like that. Sometimes the cause were the Hojoring plugins as well (due to either being slow, doing too much on the log parsing thread or spamming log lines).If you're curious, enable log line processing during imports in OverlayPlugin's settings, attach VS' profiler to the ACT process and import a log. At the very least, your DPS overlays should be updating during the log import. During the log import, check if any overlay is falling behind the other overlays. Once the import is done, check the output from the VS profiler. If you want to measure JS performance, you can also use the JS profiler in DevTools. All reactions

I was able to get the OverlayPlugin.dll by following a comment from stack overflow.1- Right-click the My Computer icon and choose Properties, or in Windows Control Panel, choose System.2- Choose Advanced system settings.3- On the Advanced tab, click Environment Variables.4- Click New to create a new environment variable under User variable section.5- Variable name: TargetFrameworkSDKToolsDirectory6- Variable value: TargetFrameworkSDKToolsDirectory=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\Windows\v10.0A\bin\NETFX 4.8 ToolsI had to browse directory so I could get the right file path.https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2986440/msbuild-on-ci-server-cant-find-al-exe All reactions

title: Unhandled exception when closing FFXIV

chats.content: When closing FFXIV, I got this exception.I thought there was a try block around UpdateEnmity, but it looks like it needs to extend around isValid as well.Maybe it's a design smell to have those side effects from isValid.---------------------------Fatal Error - Unhandled Exception---------------------------An unhandled exception has occurred.ACT may close.Press Ctrl-C to copy this MessageBox.System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception - Only part of a ReadProcessMemory or WriteProcessMemory request was completed at System.Diagnostics.NtProcessManager.GetModuleInfos(Int32 processId, Boolean firstModuleOnly) at System.Diagnostics.NtProcessManager.GetFirstModuleInfo(Int32 processId) at System.Diagnostics.Process.get_MainModule() at RainbowMage.OverlayPlugin.EventSources.FFXIVMemory.SigScan(String pattern, Int32 offset, Boolean rip_addressing) at RainbowMage.OverlayPlugin.EventSources.EnmityMemory.GetPointerAddress() at RainbowMage.OverlayPlugin.EventSources.EnmityMemory.IsValid() at RainbowMage.OverlayPlugin.EventSources.MiniParseEventSource.UpdateEnmity(Object state) at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx) at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx) at System.Threading.TimerQueueTimer.CallCallback() at System.Threading.TimerQueueTimer.Fire() at System.Threading.TimerQueue.FireNextTimers()System.Diagnostics.NtProcessManager, System, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089---------------------------OK ---------------------------The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

I think this exception should just be caught in SigScan. Since any call to that method can potentially throw such that exception (i.e. if the game crashes while we're reading a value).The same is true for any other method that calls NativeMethods.ReadProcessMemory. If this exception is caught, it should just abort and return an error code / false.For now, the PR is a good stopgap measure though and will work as far as I can see until some new code uses EnmityMemory. The only obvious downside seems to be that users will see an error being logged although I wouldn't call this an error. It's natural for the memory reading to fail if the program being read is exiting. All reactions

Download that archive, extract it using 7-Zip into %AppData%\Advanced Combat Tracker\OverlayPluginCef\x64 and create a new text file in that folder called version.txt with 75.1.14 as the content, you should be able to start ACT.Make sure you place the extracted files directly in the folder and not into a subfolder. If %AppData%\Advanced Combat Tracker\OverlayPluginCef\x64\libcef.dll exists, you've done it correctly. All reactions

This bug was introduced in 0.16.0. The issue was caused by one of the changes in the big overhaul. Due to the change, OverlayPlugin could neither read existing Label overlay configs nor create new configs. This is fixed in a27d2b1 which will be released in an update tomorrow. All reactions

title: Zoom affects overlays on same domain

chats.content: Adding from discord convo.https://discordapp.com/channels/551474815727304704/594899820976668673/743828713552085052The Zoom Slider on one overlay was affecting multiple overlays. Seems that if you have multiple overlays on the same domain the zoom affects both. The other options under general still seem to work as expected.I replicated this with my overlays at https://kalilistic.github.io/ and Ember's primary/staging at https://goldenchrysus.github.io/). This issue did not occur when I ran one of my overlays on localhost rather than the deployed version.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

This is the default Chromium behaviour (https://crbug.com/390775). Fixing this would require patching Chromium or switching to a different scaling method. The browser zoom has worked far better than the previous attempts and the additional maintenance burden that patching Chromium involves isn't justified considering how rare this bug is (you either need several instances of the same overlay or two overlays on the same domain).A more realistic solution would be using Chromium's tab api through a browser extension. Here's an example how this worksAnd here is documentation on loading extensions in CEF.This might involve a lot of edge-cases since communication between C# and the extension probably won't be easy (would most likely happen through the OverlayPluginApi which has its own share of edge-cases).I'm not interested in implementing this myself since I already have to enough on my todo list but if anyone else wants to work on this, I'd be happy to help. All reactions

title: Issue With Cactbot or Another Plugin? Please Read This!

chats.content: You will save yourself a lot of time and energy by joining the ACT Discord server and asking for help in the #troubleshooting channel or searching for your issue there. If that option is for some reason unavailable, then please ask questions in the specific plugin's GitHub repository instead (if available).This is by no means to dissuade you from posting here if you think your question is valid in that it is an issue or feature request that relates to OverlayPlugin itself or if you are simply unsure; however, for standard debugging why things aren't working, this will be the absolute slowest route to solving your issues as this repository is mostly a forum for plugin authors to discuss all things OverlayPlugin.Side note about game updates: If the game has just been updated within the last 48 hours, you will likely need to wait for the FFXIV ACT Plugin itself to update before any other plugins are updated. Again, the best place for this information would be the ACT Discord server. With recent changes to how Square Enix does things during maintenance, even a short maintenance might cause things to break.Thanks in advance!The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

title: KR6.1: Target Of Target memory has a invalid ID

chats.content: That would be `0xFFFFFFFF`, which is not a valid ID at all (it should always be `0x0`, `0x1XXXXXXX`, `0x4XXXXXXX`, or `0xE0000000`).I think at this point you'll probably have to use CheatEngine or some other memory viewing tool to track down where the disconnect is in memory address offsets, circa CombatantMemory61.cs's CombatantMemory's NPCTargetID's FieldOffset value, or you'd need to post the raw byte data of the combatant from game memory plus the expected target ID and someone here can track down the offset difference.It may help to log out the address of the combatant temporarily as well.Originally posted by @valarnin in #92 (comment)The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions
To clarify, there were also other issues indicated by the response in that PR, e.g. the BNpcNameID value was not correct, so likely all values need to be checked. All reactions

title: Cactbot P7S Purgation Stack/Spread callouts wrong after party member DC'd

chats.content: Basically the same issue as ngld#261, after a party member DCs and reconnects mid-instance the fired PartyChanged event is incomplete or otherwise incorrect in some manner, which causes cactbot's isDPS check in the P7S Inviolate Purgation trigger to come back with incorrect data.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

If I understand, it should be like this:Party member DCsOP sends incomplete infoParty member reconnectsOP sends complete infoBut it's currently like this:Party member DCsOP sends incomplete infoParty member reconnectsNothingIs that what's happening? I'd think we'd still want step 2 to happen so that there's an indication that a player has disconnected. All reactions

I haven't managed to catch this issue happening in-flight to be sure, but I think it's more like:Party member DCsOP sends complete info indicating party member has DC'dParty member reconnectsOP sends incomplete info with party member who has reconnected missing some infoTheoretically based on the code in place, there should be a 5th event where OP should send another PartyChange with complete info, but I think that's not happening for some reason. See:OverlayPlugin/OverlayPlugin.Core/EventSources/MiniParseEventSource.csLines 475 to 557in9367783 private void DispatchPartyChangeEvent(ReadOnlyCollection<uint> partyList, int partySize){cachedPartyList = partyList;var combatants = repository.GetCombatants();if (combatants == null)return; // This is a bit of a hack.The goal is to return a set of party// and alliance players, along with their jobs, ids, and names.//// |partySize| is only the size of your party, but the list of ids// contains ids from both party and alliance members.//// Additionally, there is a race where |combatants| is not updated// by the time this function is called.However, this only seems// to happen in the case of disconnects and never when zoning in.// As a workaround, we use data retrieved from the NetworkAdd/RemoveCombatant// lines and keep track of all combatants which are missing from// the memory combatant list (the network lines are missing the// party status). Once per second (in Update()) we check if all// missing members have appeared and once they do, we dispatch// a PartyChangedEvent. This should result in immediate events// whenever the party changes and a second delayed event for each// change that updates the inParty field.//// Alternatives:// * poll GetCombatants until all party members exist (infinitely?)// * find better memory location of party list// * make this function only return the values from the delegate// * make callers handle this via calling GetCombatants explicitly // Build a lookup table of currently known combatantsvar lookupTable = new Dictionary<uint, Combatant>();foreach (var c in combatants){if (GetPartyType(c) != 0 /* None */){lookupTable[c.ID] = c;}} // Accumulate party members from cached info.If they don't exist,// still send *something*, since it's better than nothing.List<PartyMember> result = new List<PartyMember>(24);lock (missingPartyMembers) lock (partyList){missingPartyMembers.Clear(); foreach (var id in partyList){Combatant c;if (lookupTable.TryGetValue(id, out c)){result.Add(new PartyMember{id = $"{id:X}",name = c.Name,worldId = c.WorldID,job = c.Job,level = c.Level,inParty = GetPartyType(c) == 1 /* Party */,});}else{missingPartyMembers.Add(id);}} if (missingPartyMembers.Count > 0) {Log(LogLevel.Debug, "Party changed event delayed until members are available");return;}} Log(LogLevel.Debug, "party list: {0}", JObject.FromObject(new { party = result }).ToString()); DispatchAndCacheEvent(JObject.FromObject(new{type = PartyChangedEvent,party = result,}));}All reactions

title: Upcoming new log lines

chats.content: I talked with quisquous and xp about this in Discord DMs, but wanted to put this up here for further discussion before working on a PR.I'm currently looking to add the following log lines:CountdownExample Data: |10001234|79|7|00|01|00|Some One|Fields: |ID|WorldID|Seconds|Result|Unknown1|Unknown2|Name|Use case: Cactbot oopsyraidsyCountdownCancelExample Data: |10001234|79|0000|Some One|Fields: |ID|WorldID|Unknown|Name|Use case: Cactbot oopsyraidsyActorSetPosExample Data: |40004ED5|1.5707|00|00|00000000|13.4825|-24.7262|0.7393|00000000|Fields: |ID|Heading|WaitForLoad?|Unknown1|Unknown2|X|Y|Z|Unknown3|Use case: General usageActorMoveExample Data: |4001512C|2.6086|00000000|92.1354|0.0000|92.3185|00000000|Fields: |ID|Heading|Unknown1|X|Y|Z|Unknown2|Use case: General usageThis packet is really spammy, so it will be limited to only enemy actors without a player owner (aka actors with an ID >= 0x40000000 that aren't pets)There are a number of other log lines that could be added as well in the future, but I'm not sure of their overall usefulness:ActorControl with a filter applied to the category, e.g. allow SetTarget, SetOwnerId, UpdateNameID, PlayActionTimeline category packets. I currently have category ID mappings for 190 categories.BattleTalk2, this is the chat that's displayed as an on-screen overlay bubble, e.g. The Lunar Subterrane Dark Elf's opening line Who dares trespass in Lord Golbez's domain?FirstAttack, might be useful for detecting "in combat" status on a per-player basisSpawnNPC, SpawnObject, SpawnPlayer, DespawnCharacter, DespawnObject - Might be more useful/reliable than 03 or 04 lines, but need significant cleanup in structure as the Sapphire project's structs for these are very incorrect for current liveUpdateHate, UpdateHater - Might be useful to replace the current enmity read from memory code?UpdateParty - Might be useful to replace the (newly-rewritten) OnPartyChanged code, but would need significant cleanup in structure, and only contains the current 8-player party, no alliance info (there are alliance-specific versions of this packet as well which I have absolutely no structure for currently)EventPlay# - Used for crafting stuff, in my extremely limited testing EventPlay4 is used when starting a craft, and EventPlay64 is used when the player uses a crafting action e.g. Basic SynthesisProbably many others as well, I have mappings for >200 opcodes currentlyThe text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

I would say, ActorMove and ActorSetPos would probably make sense as a data source (with memory as a fallback) for 261-lines rather than being their own lines, otherwise you'd have two lines conveying the same information. Same for if you later implement the Spawn* packets. All reactions

My concern in general with any of these is that extra opcodes creates more work during any patch. If you feel like this isn't an issue, then that's fine, but just noting my concern. A lot of it is that often during a patch somebody will complain about map effect lines not working and there's confusion over "my act works" vs "this log line doesn't work". I think it's a poor user experience to have things that can "half work". (That said, perhaps with countdown, we would be able to verify that OP opcodes are updated properly via a manual user test?)I would say, ActorMove and ActorSetPos would probably make sense as a data source (with memory as a fallback) for 261-lines rather than being their own lines, otherwise you'd have two lines conveying the same information. Same for if you later implement the Spawn* packets.Yeah, similar feelings here from me, especially for ActorMove.That said, I think ActorSetPos could maybe be worth having a line on its own if it's not used that often. I think I remember that valarnin mentioned elsewhere (maybe in a DM?) that it's used for things like Titan UWU jumps to a cardinal, and it'd probably be more reliable from a log line perspective to use the packet for that than even a quickly updated memory position.Other assorted thoughts:Re: spawn lines. I think in general positions are often reliable in 03 lines. I would be curious if there's a setpos/move in the cases where it feels like it's spawn (somewhere random) -> move -> starts casting (incorrect stale log line position) vs whether SpawnNPC had the right data but the 03 log line did not. If SpawnObject means "towers", then that'd probably be quite useful.Re: party lines. I think if we have a working version right now that is not opcode based, then I think we should probably stick with it unless there's a good reason to switch. The existing version sounds more reliable, and I don't see the advantage to switching here.Re: update hate / update hater. Mostly my feelings are around if this is easier to maintain than the current enmity code. That said, personally I don't think the enmity stuff has been useful in quite some time so I don't know that it's worth spending much time here. I moved the enmity code into OP so that plugin setup was easier a long time ago (similar reasons for wanting to move cactbot plugin into OP), but it's not really useful anymore. All reactions

My concern in general with any of these is that extra opcodes creates more work during any patch. If you feel like this isn't an issue, then that's fine, but just noting my concern.I think that given that @Makar8000 has been handling opcode updates for us that's more a question to them, or maybe a broader question of "can we make opcode updates something that anyone can handle".A lot of it is that often during a patch somebody will complain about map effect lines not working and there's confusion over "my act works" vs "this log line doesn't work". I think it's a poor user experience to have things that can "half work". (That said, perhaps with countdown, we would be able to verify that OP opcodes are updated properly via a manual user test?)This seems more like a plugin communication issue. Maybe we should make it more obvious to the user (or to a downstream plugin/overlay) that opcodes aren't available for the current game version?Yeah, similar feelings here from me, especially for ActorMove.That said, I think ActorSetPos could maybe be worth having a line on its own if it's not used that often. I think I remember that valarnin mentioned elsewhere (maybe in a DM?) that it's used for things like Titan UWU jumps to a cardinal, and it'd probably be more reliable from a log line perspective to use the packet for that than even a quickly updated memory position.There's already a mechanism in place in LineCombatant to trigger a log line (if the normal delay has passed since the last one) on network packet, it would be relatively easy to have e.g. ActorSetPos ignore the delay check and always force a line.ActorMove is what's used for Titan's turn-before-jumping in UWU, e.g.:Titan turns to face west:4096|2023-11-18T18:56:52.2050000-05:00|ActorMove|40013C7E|-1.5709|005A0000|100.0092|0.0000|100.0092|00000000|5f181792a8f7a73aTitan teleports:4096|2023-11-18T18:56:54.1140000-05:00|ActorSetPos|40013C7E|1.5707|00|00|00000000|86.0000|100.0000|0.0000|00000000|101bf526acdaf715ActorSetPos is used for "teleporting", e.g. Ifrit's initial position at the start of Ifrit phase before he does the initial dash with Radiant Plumes on the ground:Actor teleports:4096|2023-11-18T18:54:03.1670000-05:00|ActorSetPos|40013C82|-0.0001|00|00|00000000|100.0000|80.5000|0.0000|00000000|bde4e513b7534c6dMemory is updated. Note that the timestamp on 261 lines is user-system-clock-based, whereas packet-based lines are server-time-based:261|2023-11-18T18:54:02.7930000-05:00|Change|40013C82|Heading|0.0000|PosX|100.0000|PosY|80.5000|PosZ|0.0000|c2598e6dc472c8dfTrigger the "landing animation":4096|2023-11-18T18:54:03.2560000-05:00|ActorControl|40013C82|PlayActionTimeline|00001E43|00000000|00000000|00000000|00000000|fb133593b5c76185Memory update detects that model is visible now:261|2023-11-18T18:54:03.0310000-05:00|Change|40013C82|ModelStatus|0|6d7caa0d154e2964Starts casting the dash:20|2023-11-18T18:54:05.3460000-05:00|40013C82|Ifrit|2B5F|Crimson Cyclone|40013C82|Ifrit|2.700|100.00|80.50|0.00|0.00|eb5f92f0850c6164Other assorted thoughts:Re: spawn lines. I think in general positions are often reliable in 03 lines. I would be curious if there's a setpos/move in the cases where it feels like it's spawn (somewhere random) -> move -> starts casting (incorrect stale log line position) vs whether SpawnNPC had the right data but the 03 log line did not. If SpawnObject means "towers", then that'd probably be quite useful.It's unlikely that we would get bad position data in 03 lines just because of the way that they work (completely memory-based and only emitted when the actor is visible, which should always be after their ActorSetPos packet has been handled client-side). However, the fact that they're memory-based and therefore dependent on polling rate makes them significantly slower in some cases than SpawnXYZ packets, though for many mechanics the actor exists from the start of the fight instead of being spawned mid-fight."Objects" in this case are extremely simplified actors that will never generate e.g. a Cast line. They're more akin to housing items in their level of functionality, though they do exist in instanced battle content. I included them in the list since they also exist in the Combatants array in-memory.Re: party lines. I think if we have a working version right now that is not opcode based, then I think we should probably stick with it unless there's a good reason to switch. The existing version sounds more reliable, and I don't see the advantage to switching here.The maintainability is roughly equal, e.g. packet layout changing would be equivalent in difficulty to update to memory layout changing.I'm of two minds here because getting cross-world info is a massive pain via memory but would be relatively simple via packet, but then the need for cross-world party list is pretty limited.Re: update hate / update hater. Mostly my feelings are around if this is easier to maintain than the current enmity code. That said, personally I don't think the enmity stuff has been useful in quite some time so I don't know that it's worth spending much time here. I moved the enmity code into OP so that plugin setup was easier a long time ago (similar reasons for wanting to move cactbot plugin into OP), but it's not really useful anymore.I'm not advocating for or against this. I think that as long as the current memory code for enmity works (and there's people using it) it's fine to keep it as-is, but I wanted to make sure the option was out there if there was interest. All reactions

There's already a mechanism in place in LineCombatant to trigger a log line (if the normal delay has passed since the last one) on network packet, it would be relatively easy to have e.g. ActorSetPos ignore the delay check and always force a line.The only part that's missing currently is that the memory might not be updated with the new position data, leading to the same issue with 21 and other lines having stale data. OP would need to also track said positions itself. All reactions

Re: new opcodes:Generally speaking more opcodes won't mean more work if the automated process for it doesn't break. When something breaks (which I think was twice this expansion for me?) we can usually still do it through static analysis, but it's pretty manual (one opcode at a time) and at that point you probably wouldn't merge it until it's verified once servers are up anyways.I am fine with sharing my scripts so that others can contribute, but note that they are for IDA 7.7. It's not public more because I am a novice with this stuff and it's not very good code, but also no one has really directly asked for it. Feel free to DM me on Discord.It was basically made by studying Adam's documentation here and then remaking the scripts available here (the sigs are out of date and some other stuff was broken). There's a few other open source projects that I've seen as well that are purely based on sigs rather than comparing schema diffs between two versions. Flawed also posts an opcode diff json on the Sapphire server too that could probably be used. Outside of that, there's always the ability to find the new opcodes using the live server instead w/ Machina/FFXIVMon/etc All reactions

Re: other log lines that would be useful, especially in the context of Aloalo criterion:tethers on spawn: a long while ago when I looked into tethers for the ffxiv plugin, I couldn't figure out how to get this info out other than seeing that in some cases the target was parentActorId; from discussions with valarnin it looks like for these cases the tether target is 0x58 parentActorId and the tether id is 0x80 in the npc spawn packetActorControl's SetAnimationState: in Aloalo there's one set of bombs that lights up immediately and later sets of bombs that light up with a delay; the delay use SetAnimationState so it'd be nice to be able to figure out which one that is. I have no idea how spammy this is or how often it happens. (At least in one pull of criterion, it literally only happens in these cases.) It looks like the first set of bombs likely sets this animation state in the npc spawn packet so we could emit that line too, but that's maybe risky for the future if we don't have any other easier-to-test examples and it's less important than the later sets.Edit: Also, is BattleTalk2 the 0044 battle dialog? I still see a lot of complaints in act discord about people not having ucob quotes work right. Having this emitted by OP would be a huge help to avoiding tech support due to chat issues. All reactions

Correction on tethers, the offset is 0x7A excluding the Server_MessageHeader bytes. 0x9A when including the header bytes.imageThe game might also be copying the entire SpawnNPC packet into combatant memory at Character offset 0x1430 roughly, though I'm really not sure on this since decomp is making memcpy a giant mess. It's a 0x280 byte struct (last 8 bytes in the packet are padding I think, but if not it's 0x288 I guess). I'm not 100% sure on this though, needs some testing. If this is the case we can likely just map initialTether or something on the combatant memory structs?Edit: Also, is BattleTalk2 the 0044 battle dialog? I still see a lot of complaints in act discord about people not having ucob quotes work right. Having this emitted by OP would be a huge help to avoiding tech support due to chat issues.I think Nael quotes are instead NpcYell, current opcode 0x70? I don't have any UCOB runs, but here are some example raw packets from EW ex2 Hyd:EA13004000000000D5280000D12F000000000000000000000000000000000000EA13004000000000D5280000D22F0000000000000000000000000000000000000x2FD1 = 12241 = By blade!0x2FD2 = 12242 = Light unyielding! All reactions

Bad hex arithmetic on my part.The game might also be copying the entire SpawnNPC packet into combatant memory at Character offset 0x1430 roughly, though I'm really not sure on this since decomp is making memcpy a giant mess. If this is the case we can likely just map initialTether or something on the combatant memory structs?Huh! Yeah, I'd be good with whatever makes the most sense from a maintainability standpoint in terms of getting it from memory or getting it from network data. And maybe it doesn't matter in the sense that if one changed the other would likely change.I think Nael quotes are instead NpcYell, current opcode 0x70? I don't have any UCOB runs, but here are some example raw packets from EW ex2 Hyd:Yeah, they are. I left some comments in the ucob trigger file that link to entries in the NpcYell table, so that checks out. All reactions

I checked and unfortunately the SpawnNPC packet data isn't stored as part of the Character struct in memory, it's stored elsewhere (but I did confirm that it's stored for the lifetime of the NPC). So I think it's easier from a maintainability standpoint to pick this data up from the packet itself. All reactions

And since commonality/spamminess of AC packets was mentioned, here's a table with my data (Category is a number if I don't have a textual name for the category yet):CountPacket _ All reactions

Re: #276 (comment) for set animation state and extra info on spawning.I don't really have time to merge this (sorry), but if anybody wants to finish it off, here's an OP patch and some demo cactbot code for finding which bombs in aloalo criterion/savage are tethered to each other and when they start glowing:OP patch: https://github.com/quisquous/OverlayPlugin/commits/alo_lines/cactbot example using it: quisquous/cactbot@9d37c2d...another_alo_opNote; this doesn't handle the case when bombs start glowing on spawn. Here's some bomb spawning with offsets (Hx### = header, 0x### = packet offset, so add 0x20 to get the real offset). NE is the glowing initial bomb. If you diff the two files, you can see that 0x90 aka 0xB0 offset is (probably) the initial animation state, but it was unclear to me how big it is. You could probably add this to NpcSpawnExtra if you wanted.ne.txtn.txt All reactions

Just deleted the entire folder in AppData and reinstalled ACT. All reactions

That error indicates that files from your %AppData%\Advanced Combat Tracker\OverlayPluginCef folder are missing. OverlayPlugin automatically downloads the files again if the folder is missing. The next time you see this error, close ACT, delete said folder and open ACT again to fix the issue (should be much faster than reinstalling).Some background as to why this happens: OverlayPlugin assumes that the folder is fine if it exists since I never expected someone to delete individual files from inside the folder. I suppose some trigger-happy AV or other "cleaning" software is the cause. Either way, the next OverlayPlugin version will properly handle this error and automatically re-download the files if necessary. All reactions

title: Cactbot raidboss overlay does not work with logitech keybinds

chats.content: Using the latest ACT, overlayplugin release, and cactbot release, and I'm using LGS instead of Logitech HUB.Normal behavior is mouse keybinds will work upon alt-tabbing into the game.With a cactbot overlay, alt-tabbing into the game will confuse logitech and the keybinds will not work.The "fix" is to click the main ACT window and then click into FFXIV in order for the keybinds to work.My OverlayPlugin.dll window looks like thisThe "cact" overlay is Cactbot Raidboss preset.If I remove the "cact" overlay, then I get normal behavior once again.Another note is that clicking the cact ACTWS compatibility returns the following error message in the log, if this is relevant[7/30/2020 8:30:53 PM] Error: Error checking html rel dir: file:///C:/Users/fruit/AppData/Roaming/ACT%20Plugins/cactbot-0.18.4/cactbot/ui/raidboss/raidboss.html?timeline=1&alerts=0&HOST_PORT=ws://127.0.0.1/fake/: System.ArgumentException: Illegal characters in path. at System.Security.Permissions.FileIOPermission.EmulateFileIOPermissionChecks(String fullPath) at System.Security.Permissions.FileIOPermission.QuickDemand(FileIOPermissionAccess access, String fullPath, Boolean checkForDuplicates, Boolean needFullPath) at Cactbot.CactbotEventSource.GetUserConfigDirAndFiles(String source, String& config_dir, Dictionary`2& local_files)[7/30/2020 8:30:53 PM] Info: cact: BrowserConsole: CSS cannot be loaded from `file:` URLs unless they end in a `.css` file extension. (Source: , Line: 0)The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

The error isn't relevant since that's the expected outcome. The option explicitly mentions that you should never use ACTWS compatibility with any overlay that was built for OverlayPlugin (since it breaks those).My guess (as per the discussion on Discord) is that Logitech is confused by the overlay windows and doesn't realize that the game is focused. Windows's window stack is a bit weird in that regard. If you configure your macros in Logitech's software to work for both FFXIV and ACT (pretend ACT is a game), they should work as expected. All reactions
This was solved on Discord. All reactions

Does this happen if you launch ACT first and FFXIV afterwards or does it only happen if you launch FFXIV first?Most likely this is a race condition. The FFXIV plugin starts sending log lines as soon as it's loaded. However, OverlayPlugin only starts receiving log lines once ACT is done loading plugins.My theory is that the startup takes longer with Hojoring, long enough in fact that the initial zone log line is processed before OverlayPlugin is ready.This is expected behavior. If you want the full and accurate game state in ACT, you have to start ACT first or change your zone at least once. All reactions
i always have FFXIV up and running when i did my tests.(by just closing ACT and reopening after a while to make sure its fully closed in task manager) All reactions

Can OverlayPlugin subscribe to logs earlier?I think the unexpected part for me is that ChangeZoneEvent is a cached event.So, my expectation is that OverlayPlugin should always send this event as soon as I subscribe, if the game is on and I am therefore in some zone.Similarly, the ChangePrimaryPlayerEvent. All reactions

just as a little side note: i also have trouvle with enmity memory when hojouring is loaded, when ACT starts. My current workaround is: disabling hojouring, restart act, wait till Info: Found enmity memory for 5.4. is displayed in the logs, enable hojouring again. All reactions

OverlayPlugin could subscribe to the logs earlier. However, since the event source subscribes to the log event, that'd require starting up the built in event sources earlier which would also mean that the built in event sources would have to start much earlier than i.e. Cactbot's event source which I'd rather avoid since it adds complexity and potential for errors.Cached events only work if OverlayPlugin has the information in the first place. The only thing that's always available is memory data since that's read constantly. Log and network based data are only available once OverlayPlugin has seen the relevant packets / log lines.I could add a disclaimer that some data might be missing until you change your zone if you start ACT after FFXIV though I'm not sure where I'd put that disclaimer (in the dev docs? The UI?). I'm not really willing to change this either since it's a natural consequence of the parser design and will always remain an issue as long as we rely on raw network data anywhere. I also doubt the effort required to fix this is worth saving the player a teleport.@Akurosia Can you describe your issue in more detail? Do you get errors or any other messages related to memory? How long does it take for the Found enmity memory message to show up? All reactions

OverlayPlugin could subscribe to the logs earlier.What about subscribing to logs earlier with some other handler and stashing them somewhere until everything else is set up, and then processing everything then?I agree that log data is only available once OverlayPlugin has seen the log line, but these aren't log lines like combat data that existed five minutes ago, they are log lines that get sent every time when the parser plugin starts writing to a log file.It feels like these shouldn't be missed and OverlayPlugin is missing them due to a race.I guess arguably you could enable OverlayPlugin after ACT startup.Maybe we could get some way to ask the parser plugin to resend all the header logs that start every log file.I also doubt the effort required to fix this is worth saving the player a teleport.Sorry to push back on this, but many people zone into a raid and then start ACT.Additionally, sometimes your computer crashes and you need to restart ACT while you're in a zone.It's not clear when you're in this state, and you're not always in a place where you can teleport. All reactions

If we buffer the log lines, the ChangePrimaryPlayer and ChangeZone events would work as expected but it won't fix the OnlineStatusChanged and PartyChanged events. To fix the PartyChanged event, I'd have to also register the PartyChangeDelegate early. At that point it's probably easier to start the event source earlier. Finally, there's nothing I can do to fix the OnlineStatusChanged event but I doubt anyone cares about that (since it's mostly used for cutscene detection).If I register the PartyChangeDelegate early, loading OverlayPlugin after the FFXIV plugin becomes a hard requirement but most people seem to do that anyway. I can probably display a warning if I detect that OverlayPlugin is loaded before the FFXIV plugin to work around that issue.I'll probably have to split the load phases, then. The FFXIV integration has to be enabled early so we can register the PartyChangeDelegate but the Trigg integration has to be enabled late because I can't rely on people loading Trigg before OverlayPlugin. Nothing uses the Trigg integration directly so that should be fine.To register the event handlers, it's enough to create the event source instances early, I don't have to start them so it shouldn't mess with other stuff like the config UI.This wouldn't cause Cactbot's own event source to start any earlier but I don't think it's affected because it doesn't listen to any ACT or FFXIV events in the first place. All reactions

title: Overlays reset scale and position on ACT restart.

chats.content: Since the latest version update, on startup of ACT the scaling for Cactbot and Kagerou is shrunk and they also have their positioning changed from where they were saved. The scaling corrects itself as soon as the overlay is unlocked and dragged.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

This is more or less a duplicate of #13 and caused by missing high DPI support in ACT. Windows tries to scale the overlays itself which just causes them to glitch like you described. Your best bet is to disable the scaling by opening ACT's compatibility settings and setting the scaling mode to Application.You can then use the zoom slider in the overlay settings to scale the overlay. All reactions

title: [Question] Reasons for high data traffic

chats.content: According to appnetworkcounter's monitoring ACT itself downloads about 1GB to 2GB data in More than half a day.The only other plugins used are cactbot and Hojoring.Is this high traffic volume due to the overlay plugin?overlay plugin log will show the following error.Error: Update for EnmityEventSource took too long, skipping overlapping tick!This may appear more than once over time.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

This is just a random guess... but if it is OverlayPlugin, my guess is whatever software you have isn't correctly accounting for the fact that the CEF process is transferring data to/from a local connection.The "high data traffic" never leaves your computer, so shouldn't be counted as something abnormal.1GB in 12 hours is 24KB/s?Maybe a little more than I would expect from mini parse data, but multiple overlays could multiply that. All reactions

This is just a random guess... but if it is OverlayPlugin, my guess is whatever software you have isn't correctly accounting for the fact that the CEF process is transferring data to/from a local connection. The "high data traffic" never leaves your computer, so shouldn't be counted as something abnormal. 1GB in 12 hours is 24KB/s? Maybe a little more than I would expect from mini parse data, but multiple overlays could multiply that.Thank you EQAditu for your reply... And I am sorry for the late reply.The investigation was incomplete, but various subsequent checks revealed nothing unusual.In addition to setting up too many overlays,It occurs when communication fails due to home network security and attempts are repeated.So I closed this post now. All reactions

title: ACT起動時のアプリケーションエラー

chats.content: お世話になっております。これまで、本家のOverlayPluginを使用していたのですが、こちらの存在を知り乗り換えさせていただきました。その後の話なのですが、ACT起動時のPlugin読み込み中に、ACTが強制終了する現象に悩まされております。手順としては、単にACTを起動するだけなのですが、読み込み中のプログレスバーが表示されている最中にプログレスバーが消え、そのままACTが起動しない状態です。ただし、これは毎回起きるわけではなく、たまに発生します。Windows起動直後のACT実行で起きやすいです。ACT自体のログにエラーはなく、Windowsのイベントビューアーに以下のログが残っていました。障害が発生しているアプリケーション名: Advanced Combat Tracker.exe、バージョン: 3.4.2.262、タイム スタンプ: 0x5d745660障害が発生しているモジュール名: libcef.DLL、バージョン: 3.2454.1320.0、タイム スタンプ: 0x566542f0例外コード: 0x80000003障害オフセット: 0x0000000001f887b4障害が発生しているプロセス ID: 0x377c障害が発生しているアプリケーションの開始時刻: 0x01d56711bf8fe8fa障害が発生しているアプリケーション パス: C:\Program Files (x86)\Advanced Combat Tracker\Advanced Combat Tracker.exe障害が発生しているモジュール パス: C:\Program Files (x86)\Advanced Combat Tracker\plugin\OverlayPlugin\libcef.DLLレポート ID: bb35a7b7-1a04-4b0d-8251-fa6dbde6b591障害が発生しているパッケージの完全な名前:障害が発生しているパッケージに関連するアプリケーション ID:使用OS：Windows10 1903 64bitPluginバージョン：0.3.4.0私ではこれ以上手詰まりになってしまい、なにかおわかりでしたら教えていただきたく。ちなみに、少しカスタマイズしており、ビルドは自分で行っております。ビルド自体はエラーがなく完了しており、libcef.dll自体も差分比較しても、こちらで配布されているものと差分はありませんでした。The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions
libcef.dllは事前に作成されたCEFライブラリあるので、ビルドを再実行しても結果は同じように見えます。こちらのフォークがCEFを最新の状態に置き換えたので、0.5.0バージョンで確認ください。ps: 0x80000003はE_INVALIDARG、CEFの内部エラーと推測されます。 All reactions
お返事ありがとうございます。こちらからさらにForkされたものがあるとは知りませんでした。一旦0.5.0を使用して様子を見てみます。 All reactions

title: Catbot alert and dps meter down?

Any time the game executable is changed by a patch, the FFXIV_ACT_Plugin needs to be updated to support the new version.As such, usually nothing will work when a new game update comes out. Occasionally, chat log lines will still work, which is what the cactbot timeline is currently based on, because those are read from memory and not from network data.The FFXIV_ACT_Plugin was updated with a beta earlier today, and an official full release at 6:53PM EST. Please ensure you are running FFXIV_ACT_Plugin version 2.6.6.6 or newer. All reactions

title: Some html input element types do not work properly in an overlay

chats.content: I was trying to add config options for target bar replacements, and discovered thatanddo not work properly.The popups when you click on either of them do not show up when they are in an overlay but work fine in a browser.Edited to add: this is not a dealbreaker and I will just work around it, but mentioning it as a drive-by bug.The text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

This might be an issue with the way I implemented Chromium's popup rendering (to clarify: this isn't used to render popups, instead it's used by the default <select> widget).IIRC I didn't implement this because it'd require an internal bitmap buffer and additional blit calls. It's fairly easy to fix (at least for <select>); if you modify the overall appearance with CSS, Chromium will render the widget as a normal DOM element and won't use the popup renderer. All reactions

title: Proposal: a better js api workflow

chats.content: Currently OverlayPlugin have a very poor JS api document (like missing saveData and loadData),and we have written lots of code about overlay plugin's api with type definition in our cactbot repo.I proposal we move code related to api (like our ts version overlay_plugin_api.ts) provided by OverlayPlugin to this repo from cactbot, and release a npm package, use this npm package in our cactbot repo.This is hard when OverlayPlugin is controlled by ngld, but now we are maintaining, it's possible and make developers easy to write new overlay and simplify code of cactbot.by migrating TypeScript code from cactbot, it also provide a better document so user don't need to find it's implement in csharp code, type declaration will speak for it self.third part using exampleuse in third part code:import { callOverlayHandler } from 'overlay-plugin';compatibilityIn our document, we provide a script to users, so we need to build a extra file and release it to gh-pages branch to not break any previous users.type extendingTypeScript supporting declaration merging, api provided by third part plugin (like cactbot source) can be added by declaration merging.we provide a .d.ts like this:declare global {namespace OverlayPlugin {interface IAddOverlayListener {(event: 'LogLine', cb: (ev: { type: 'LogLine'; line: string[]; rawLine: string; }) => void): void;(event: 'PartyChanged', cb: (ev: { type: 'PartyChanged'; party: Party[]; }) => void): void;// catch-all for yet un-document api(event: string, cb: (ev: unknown) => void): void;}interface ICallOverlayHandler {(msg: { call: 'saveData'; key: string; data: unknown }): Promise<void>;<T = unknown>(msg: { call: 'loadData'; key: string; }): Promise<({ data?: T } | undefined)>;(msg: { call: 'getCombatants'; ids?: number[]; names?: string[]; props?: string[]; }): Promise<{ combatants: PluginCombatantState[] }>;(msg: { call: 'broadcast'; source: string; msg: unknown; }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'subscribe'; events: string[]; }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'openWebsiteWithWS'; url: string; }): Promise<void>;// catch-all for yet un-document api(msg: { call: string; }): Promise<unknown>;}}}declare global {const callOverlayHandler: OverlayPlugin.ICallOverlayHandler;const addOverlayListener: OverlayPlugin.IAddOverlayListener;}and in cactbot, it's possible to be extended by this:declare global {namespace OverlayPlugin {interface ICallOverlayHandler {(msg: { call: 'cactbotReloadOverlays' }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'cactbotRequestState' }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'cactbotSay'; text: string }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'cactbotSaveData'; overlay: string; data: unknown }): Promise<void>;(msg: { call: 'cactbotLoadData'; overlay: string }): Promise<{ data: SavedConfig } | undefined>;(msg: { call: 'cactbotChooseDirectory' }): Promise<{ data: string } | undefined>;}}}@MaikoTanThe text was updated successfully, but these errors were encountered: All reactions

I'm a bit late to the party, but given that the events are created in C#-land, wouldn't it make sense for event fields and such to be defined somewhere in C#, and then translated to TS? Having it in C# seems to address several of the aforementioned issues as well as plugging the obvious hole which is that AFAICT there's zero validation that the event emitted by the C# side actually conforms to the TS type. Making the API spec in TS when the events are generated by C# seems to just shift the issue around -rather than having to remember to update docs, now you have to remember to update TS defs when creating a new event or adding fields. Doing the defs in C# would fix both of these - you know it actually conforms, and there's nothing additional you have to remember to update.On a cursory glance, it seems there are many "C# to TS type def generator" libraries and projects out there, so it seems feasible from a tech standpoint. All reactions

Please note that there's already a 3rd party NPM package with TS declarations which has been around for 3 years: https://www.npmjs.com/package/ffxiv-overlay-apiI think to get them separated would be better, but we should explicitly mention (in readme or somewhere) that what js package version is compatiable with what overlay plugin c# side version.This is exactly why I never wanted an NPM package and the docs tell devs to directly include the JS file from the OverlayPlugin repo instead. You can't expect overlays to update whenever there's a change to the JS API. In general, the main reason for the script was to act as a wrapper around whatever browser runtime OverlayPlugin uses, just in case I'd have to switch it (again). Thankfully, that never happened and there were never any significant changes to the script and by now the point is probably moot.Assuming the internal JS API (specifically the window.OverlayPluginApi object and window.__OverlayCallback) won't change in the near future, the best path forward (IMO anyway) would be to talk with the devs for the existing NPM package and improve the type definitions. Generating the event structs from C# sounds nice but I have no idea how hard that would be to setup or maintain. All reactions
